DOC.HEAD: Posthumous Court Victory For AIDS Victim
DOC.TEXT: A man who died of AIDS won a posthumous legal victory in his fight with a nail salon that refused to give him a pedicure. The state Court of Appeals on Wednesday upheld the constitutionality of a West Hollywood ordinance that bans discrimination against people with acquired immune deficiency syndrome. Paul Jasperson had sued Jessica's Nail Salon for cancelling his July 1986 appointment for a pedicure after he mentioned to a client that he had AIDS. ``I'm just overwhelmed with happiness. I spoke at his funeral. ... All of us wanted to win this for Paul and for the millions of people with AIDS,'' his attorney, Gloria Allred, said Thursday. In a March 1988 Los Angeles County Superior Court ruling, a judge found that Jasperson was denied service because of his illness, but refused to issue an injunction. Judge Lawrence Waddington ruled that the pedicure potentially exposed salon workers to AIDS, and the risk, though marginal, was unacceptable. Jasperson, 37, died of AIDS in May, but his appeal continued. On Wednesday, the three-member Second Circuit Court of Appeals court ruled 2-1 to reverse the lower court ruling and enforce the ordinance. The court said the ordinance, by preventing discrimination, serves a public health function by encouraging those with AIDS to make their illness known to ``providers of personal services,'' who then can take precautions. ``This case was extremely important, because we were seeking to enforce the West Hollywood city ordinance which had been used as a model and copied by many other cities throughout the nation,'' Ms. Allred said. Attorneys for Santa Monica and Los Angeles, which have similar ordinances, had filed briefs on behalf of Jasperson, as did the city of West Hollywood and the American Civil Liberties Union of Southern California.
